title: iOS 15.4 Is Here: Unlock Your iPhone With a Mask On, Hear Siri's New Voice; Apple's latest iPhone software update also offers new emojis, some enhanced AirTag antistalking warnings and more
text:
The story of the Covid-19 pandemic—and the great battle to unlock our iPhones with masks on—shall be told in iOS variants:

iOS 13.5 (May 2020)—Realizing that wearing a mask prevents Face ID from reading your face and unlocking your iPhone, Apple releases a software update that makes it quicker to get to the password screen.

iOS 14.5 (April 2021)—Realizing that passwords are a real pain, Apple releases a software update that allows those with an Apple Watch to unlock their iPhones with a mask on.

iOS 15.4 (March 2022)—Realizing that all of that isn't what people really want, Apple finally releases an update that lets you unlock Face ID while wearing a mask. No password punch-in needed. Just, you know, two years too late.

With the release of iOS 15.4 on Monday, our long iPhone-mask-unlock nightmare ends. The software update also includes new emojis, an additional Siri voice and more. It will be available as a free download for 2015's iPhone 6s and later. The mask feature will only work on the iPhone 12 models and later.

When setting up Face ID with a Mask, you can't actually wear a mask. PHOTO: JOANNA STERN/THE WALL STREET JOURNAL

As I always say, the question isn't if—but when—you'll upgrade to the latest version of iOS.

If you can, hold off a few days, at least until any potential issues have been fixed. I've seen some small bugs here and there while testing the beta versions on an iPhone 12 Pro.

I can understand if you just can't wait another millisecond to stop mashing in your password or to get the new lip-bite emoji. Here's a quick review of the features that will hit your iPhone and where you can find them:

Face ID with a Mask

When you install iOS 15.4, a prompt will ask if you would like to set up Face ID with a Mask. (You can also access it from Settings > Face ID & Passcode.)

To set it up, you'll need to go through the whole rotate-your-head-like-a-yoga-instructor process to rescan your face. This is because the system needs to collect more information about the unique features around your eye area. When your face is concealed with a mask, Face ID will rely on those features to confirm it's you. You can't wear a mask when enrolling your face. If you do, you'll be told to remove it.

You will feel like Harry Houdini the first time you see the padlock unlock with your mask on. A glance at the screen while wearing your mask (I've tried cloth, surgical, N95s and KN95s) and, boom! You're in. And just like regular Face ID, you can use it to confirm your Apple Pay transactions or autofill saved passwords.

There are a few drawbacks. Since it needs to see the area around your eyes, Apple says it doesn't support sunglasses. I found that to be true for two pairs of sunglasses, but one pair that had more transparent lenses worked just fine.

Like with regular Face ID, Apple is scanning your face, something that can raise privacy concerns. But the company encrypts the data and saves it to a secure part of your iPhone's processor. It doesn't go to Apple's servers.

The more you cover your face with a mask on, the less likely the new Face ID feature will be able to unlock the phone. PHOTO: JOANNA STERN/THE WALL STREET JOURNAL

As for regular glasses, if you didn't go through the setup with them on, you'll likely want to do another scan with them. Apple says it works best when it's set up to recognize each pair of glasses.

I've also found that hats—specifically winter beanies—can interfere. If my hat blocks more of my forehead and the top of an eye, the system doesn't seem to have enough information to let me in. Raising up the hat off my eyebrows seems to do the trick.

Apple also warns that Face ID with a Mask is less accurate than without a mask. I have certainly experienced some failed unlock attempts over the past month, but in that case I just input my passcode, something I got very good at over the past two years.

Siri's New Voice

In an effort to bring more diversity to Siri, the assistant no longer defaults to a female voice, and last year, Apple added voices recorded by Black actors. iOS 15.4 adds another American voice, designed to beless explicitly male or female. A company spokeswoman confirmed that it was recorded by a member of the LGBTQ+ community.

To check it out, go to Settings > Siri & Search > Siri Voice and select Voice 5. Feel free to try some other options: I'm a big British > Voice 2 fan. I like to imagine Hugh Grant setting my kitchen timer.

In iOS 15.4, you can now customize the skin tone of both hands in this handshake emoji. PHOTO: JOANNA STERN/THE WALL STREET JOURNAL

New Emojis

A mirrored disco ball, a drained battery, a melting face, a bird's nest, a saluting face, coral, beans. The new iOS is stocked with lots of random new emojis. One of the more hidden but awesome additions? You can now choose separate skin tones for each hand in the handshake emoji. Just hold down on the handshake emoji and you'll see a new interface where you can pick a skin tone for each hand.

Add AirTag Warnings

Since their release about a year ago, AirTags, Apple's lost-item trackers, have sparked privacy and safety concerns—such as stalking or other surveillance. If you set up an AirTag with an iPhone with iOS 15.4, you'll now get an added warning that states that using the item to track people without their consent is a crime in many places.

Other Things

There are lots of other things, too. A new tap-to-pay feature enables businesses to accept Apple Pay payments using another iPhone—no payment terminal needed. Safari can now translate Italian and traditional Chinese webpages. The Podcasts app, which still needs a lot of work, at least now lets you filter by seasons, played, unplayed, saved and downloaded episodes.

Then there's the long-anticipated Universal Control, which is more an iPadOS 15.4 and MacOS Monterey 12.3 feature than an iOS 15.4 feature. Nevertheless, you can now drag your cursor from your Mac over to your iPad, making them feel like one continuous computer. Check out my colleague Dalvin Brown's video on how it all works.

Still missing from iOS 15.4? Support for the long-promised digital driver's licenses. For that we wait until some future iOS variant.
